Kiki Walker.Action: Speaks positively about Jerry, calling him a good friend and acknowledging their shared struggles.
Mocks someone else with a biting comment about doing better with teeth in a cold shower.
Acknowledges Eloise's talent and admits she got the breaks, showing understanding and humility.
Screams and climbs on dressing table in terror when panther enters the room.
Responds with humor and playful sarcasm to Jerry's idea, but shows loyalty by not rejecting him outright.
Dismisses Jerry's reassurance about the leopard and insists 'Get him out!'
Keeps her eyes purposely averted from Jerry when he seeks a comforting sign of friendliness.
Dismisses Jerry's suggestion to help with funeral expenses, telling him 'Don't be soft' and pulling sharply at his arm.
Firmly tells Jerry not to be soft and pulls sharply at his arm to emphasize the point when he suggests slipping money for funeral expenses.
Pats Jerry's arm as a friendly gesture when passing by.
Engages Jerry in conversation, showing concern about his feelings and asking questions about the other man.
Asks insightful questions about the situation, e.g. inquiring about the other man who seemed to have expert testimony.
Does not intervene or assert herself during official discussion but follows Jerry hesitantly and slowly from the scene.
Makes a movement to comfort Jerry but then restrains herself, showing emotional control and awareness of social context.
Fails to notice the approaching Delgado family, needing Senor Delgado to ask for room, indicating momentary inattentiveness or lack of situational awareness.
Bitterly complains about wild animals causing problems, showing frustration but not hostility.
Shows interest in meeting Galbraith and politely engages in conversation.
Slowly leaves the room after conversation, no dismissive or negative behavior.
Acknowledges the leopard incident frankly, shows acceptance of unpopularity without complaint.
Conveys hard look at Jerry possibly indicating frustration or blame.
Acknowledges the calamity with a hard look and realistic assessment of the situation.
Admits to not being a popular favorite due to her involvement with the leopard incident.
Prepares to perform next with confidence despite recent negative events.
Not present in the excerpt; no actions or statements to evaluate warmth.
Amusedly draws attention to herself when Eloise is focused elsewhere.
Accepts flowers intended as a kind gesture and honestly shares that they are meant for a funeral, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Gently communicates to Jerry her wish to take the flowers to the cemetery and asks if he minds, showing consideration and politeness.
Admits to feeling sadness and vulnerability, expresses care for Jerry and their relationship, openly shares emotions and softness.
Impulsively puts her arms around Jerry and hugs him affectionately.
Smiles at the old gatekeeper.
Defiantly admits to dividing money between two families, showing honesty and fairness.
Politely refuses to sit beside Robles despite his beseeching gesture.
No direct action or involvement in the passage; remains absent from critical interactions and decisions.
Acknowledges the challenges she faces in her career but remains hopeful and confident about her future, recognizing the efforts made by her press agent Jerry and herself.
Mocks another character to indicate superiority, suggesting some self-assuredness and social skill.
Relies heavily on Jerry, her press agent, to solve her problems and advance her career, showing dependence on others' competence.
Turns quickly and rises in terror upon seeing the panther, screams, and climbs onto the dressing table to keep distance.
Commands to 'Get it out of here!' showing assertiveness despite fear.
Commands to get the leopard out despite Jerry's assurances, showing control over the situation.
Responds sarcastically and confidently to Jerry's plan, indicating awareness and assertiveness.
Does not express fear or hesitation even when confronted with a dangerous animal nearby.
Lets Jerry help her down carefully while keeping a wary eye on the leopard and stands as far away from the beast as the leash permits.
Grins when given a somewhat risky and unusual task, showing readiness to engage with the challenge.
Responds flatly and sarcastically at Jerry's sentimental statements, suggesting emotional guardedness but possibly quick wit.
Turns exasperated and retorts sharply to Eloise's mocking comment, demonstrating confidence and assertiveness but possibly social friction.
Moves majestically forward leading a dangerous leopard through a crowded cafe; relies on the waiter to make a place for her, showing some social grace.
Surreptitiously nervous despite trying to maintain a dramatic and composed pose in front of the crowd.
Lets the leopard lunge forward when startled, losing control of the animal which could endanger others.
Moves majestically forward with a dangerous leopard on a leash, commanding presence despite nervousness.
Is surreptitiously nervous despite dramatic pose.
Loses control of the leopard when it is startled and lunges forward; leash pulled from her hand.
Lets the castanets go loudly which startles the leopard, resulting in losing control of its leash.
Stands trembling in fright after the leopard escapes.
Shows awareness of the situation by expressing anger and recognition of the problem ('Now look what you've done.'), indicating some self-awareness.
Hands money quietly to the nun to help with the Delgado family's funeral expenses despite feeling ill at ease in their grief.
Fumbles out a small soiled sheaf of bills from purse and discreetly donates them to the nun to help with funeral expenses.
Appears somewhat abased and very ill at ease in the presence of the grieving Delgado family.
Makes a movement as if to put her hand comfortingly on Jerry's sleeve, then changes her mind, dropping her hand.
Moves hurriedly out of the way to let the little group of mourners pass when asked.
Welcomes Jerry warmly into her dressing room and engages in light, teasing conversation, indicating familiarity and friendliness.
Maintains a somewhat sarcastic tone ('Well, does everybody love us now?') but without malice, suggesting a playful interaction.
Intercepts Jerry's attempt to deceive by asking if he found the leopard, showing she is aware of his actions.
Reading a magazine in an armchair before Jerry's arrival, appears relaxed and confident.
Recognizes the tension and underlying issues with the leopard situation; presses Jerry for information showing awareness and insight.
Expresses bitterness about the wild animals interfering with their first real break, showing realistic understanding of the impact on the show.
Passively picks up her hat and goes toward the door slowly without pressing further or taking active steps to help with the problem.
Follows Jerry and asks polite questions, showing social engagement and some curiosity but no initiative or leadership.
Is normally curious and asks Galbraith questions without realizing she is prying.

Asks curious and relevant questions to Galbraith, showing engagement and interest.
Unaware that her questions might be considered prying; shows naivety or social unawareness.
Admits not being much of a success especially after a failed publicity stunt, showing awareness but also hinting at a professional setback.
No actions, statements, or internal behaviors present in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Joins a light, friendly social moment, responds with amused awareness.
Prepared for travel, dressed appropriately in a suit with hat and topcoat ready.
Engages confidently in casual conversation, indicates readiness to use free time to rest.
Quietly insists on taking the flowers to the cemetery, showing sensitivity and subtle communication.
Hesitates and is a little shame-faced when requesting to take flowers to the cemetery, indicating vulnerability but also thoughtful decision-making.
Reflects thoughtfully on emotional matters and admits vulnerability, showing self-awareness and emotional intelligence.
Focuses on feelings and relationships rather than practical solutions or actions in the scene, showing limited active problem-solving behavior.
Decides to stay and catch a murderer instead of leaving; shows determination to make the town safe and happy.
Remembers and questions Jerry about financial matters (closing check), indicating practical awareness.
Admits to being out of cash and having spent money on jewelry impulsively.
Refuses to sit beside Robles despite his request, showing some discomfort or reluctance.
Encourages Jerry with confidence to continue their investigation despite setbacks.
Steps into the lighted alcove and apologizes for disturbing Galbraith, explaining she came on the spur of the moment.
Arrives unexpectedly and apologizes politely for disturbing Galbraith.
Approaches Galbraith apologetically and smiles uncertainly, showing consideration and a gentle demeanor.
Encourages Galbraith to turn off the lights to see the procession better, showing trust and a desire to share an experience.
Persists kindly despite Galbraith's hesitation, demonstrating patience and concern.
Is terrified internally but does not explicitly frighten or intimidate Galbraith.
Stands perfectly still and watches the window despite her anxiety, controlling her outward reactions to avoid alerting Galbraith.
Shows fear internally (rising hand to heart, heartbeat sounds) but does not flee or cry out until Galbraith moves violently toward her.
Screams only when physically threatened suddenly, indicating a reactive rather than proactive response to danger.
Steps backward to avoid a struggle but accidentally knocks over a glass display case, falling with it and causing a loud crash.
Quickly reassures Jerry she is not hurt after falling, showing self-control and calmness under pressure.
Openly expresses complex emotions and insights about past events, showing self-awareness and emotional intelligence.
Engages in sincere dialogue about personal and communal troubles, indicating thoughtful reflection rather than impulsive behavior.
